Introduction

Tonsillitis, or inflammation of the palatine tonsils, is a common cause of sore throat in children.  Distinguishing between viral and bacterial etiologies is essential for guiding management because bacterial tonsillitis has the potential for significant complications.

Pathogenesis



The palatine tonsils are lymphatic tissues that trap inhaled or ingested pathogens and help initiate an immune response.  Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils caused by viruses or bacteria; concomitant infection of the oropharynx is referred to as tonsillopharyngitis.  Infection is typically transmitted through respiratory droplets, after which tonsillar epithelial cells are invaded and a release of proinflammatory cytokines occurs, resulting in localized inflammation and often systemic symptoms.

Viral tonsillitis



The majority of tonsillar infections are caused by respiratory viruses (eg, rhinovirus, adenovirus).  These viruses typically demonstrate low virulence, and the infections rarely result in complications.  However, the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is also a common viral cause of tonsillitis that often leads to systemic and sometimes prolonged illness (infectious mononucleosis).  Less common causes of viral tonsillitis should be considered in those who are unvaccinated (eg, measles) and/or immunocompromised (eg, cytomegalovirus).

Bacterial tonsillitis



Streptococcus pyogenes (group A Streptococcus [GAS]) is the most common cause of bacterial tonsillitis.  Uncommon bacterial infections that should be considered are based primarily on risk factors:



  • Unvaccinated:  Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Sexually active:  Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Adolescents/young adults:  Fusobacterium necrophorum.

Clinical presentation



Tonsillitis can occur at any age, but children age 5-15 are most susceptible.  Classic presenting symptoms include acute-onset fever and sore throat.  Dysphagia and halitosis may develop secondary to tonsillar inflammation.  Nonspecific systemic symptoms can include fatigue and loss of appetite.  The primary physical examination finding is symmetrically swollen, erythematous tonsils, which may be accompanied by anterior cervical lymphadenopathy.  In severe cases of tonsillitis (uncommon), marked tonsillar inflammation may lead to airway obstruction.



Historical and examination findings may suggest a viral or bacterial etiology.

Viral tonsillitis



Common viral etiologies (eg, rhinovirus, adenovirus) typically cause low-grade fever, absent or mucoid tonsillar exudate, and other symptoms consistent with a viral upper respiratory infection (eg, cough, rhinorrhea, conjunctivitis).



EBV tonsillitis differs from other viral etiologies, often presenting with prolonged fever (up to 1 month) and thick tonsillar exudate.  Additional clinical features in infectious mononucleosis include posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and marked fatigue (

figure 1
).

Bacterial tonsillitis



Tonsillitis due to bacterial infection is more commonly associated with high fever and thick, purulent tonsillar exudate (

image 1
).  Certain features may suggest a specific etiology: palatal petechiae (
image 2
) in GAS pharyngitis or a white-gray, adherent, friable pseudomembrane in diphtheria.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Tonsillitis is a clinical diagnosis based on edematous, erythematous tonsils in the setting of a sore throat.  Those with concomitant cough and without fever or tonsillar exudate are usually diagnosed with viral tonsillitis, and testing is generally unnecessary.



A clinical scoring system (Centor criteria) is often used in the evaluation of suspected streptococcal tonsillitis in adults and primarily guides the need for microbiologic testing (

figure 2
).  These clinical rules are less predictive in children, so microbiologic testing is typically recommended in children who have no other symptoms of a viral illness (eg, cough, discrete ulcers).  The test of choice is a rapid antigen test for GAS.  A throat culture should be obtained in cases of negative rapid antigen testing, which can have false-negative results.



When infectious mononucleosis is suspected, the diagnosis is made using the heterophile antibody (Monospot) test, which detects EBV antibodies that agglutinate to horse or sheep red blood cells.  However, this test is not accurate in children age <4, and there is a high false-negative rate during the first week of illness.  In these cases, serum anti-EBV–specific antibody testing should be used:  The presence of viral capsid antigen IgM antibodies (plus an absence of IgG antibodies to EBV nuclear antigen) is diagnostic of acute infection.

Differential diagnosis



  • Tonsil hypertrophy:  Noninfectious hypertrophy of the tonsils is a relatively common condition in young children and may cause symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea (eg, snoring, noisy breathing).  Sore throat and fever are absent, and, although the tonsils are enlarged on examination, they lack erythema or exudate.
  • Tonsilloliths:  Calcified accumulations of food and cellular debris within the tonsillar crypts can result in recurrent sore throat and halitosis.  Fever and tonsillar erythema are not associated with this condition.

Prognosis and management



Viral infections typically self-resolve within 1-2 weeks, and supportive care with analgesia (eg, ibuprofen) and hydration is recommended.  GAS pharyngitis warrants antibiotic therapy to decrease the risk for complications.  First-line therapy includes penicillin or amoxicillin; azithromycin, clindamycin, or cephalexin can be used in those with penicillin allergy.  Oral corticosteroids are not routinely used to treat tonsillitis but can be considered as adjunctive therapy in cases of severe inflammation, particularly if there is concern for airway narrowing.



Less common bacterial causes are usually considered when either supportive care or GAS treatment is not curative and often require pathogen-specific testing (eg, nucleic acid amplification testing for gonorrhea, special culture media for diphtheria).

Complications



Serious suppurative and nonsuppurative complications of bacterial tonsillitis can occur.

Suppurative (acute, direct extension of bacteria)



  • Peritonsillar abscess (
    figure 3
    ):  A purulent collection can develop between the tonsil and the pharyngeal muscles, causing sore throat and fever, in addition to a muffled voice, trismus, and unilateral swelling of the posterior pharynx with uvular deviation.
  • Lemierre syndrome:  F necrophorum tonsillitis can result in septic thrombophlebitis secondary to local invasion of the pharyngeal space and internal jugular vein.  Findings include unilateral tenderness, swelling, and induration over the neck.  Seeding of multiple organs with septic emboli can occur with or without septic shock.

Nonsuppurative (immune-mediated, delayed sequelae of GAS)



  • Acute rheumatic fever (
    figure 4
    ):  After untreated GAS pharyngitis, acute rheumatic fever (a multisystem, autoimmune disease) can manifest as arthritis, pancarditis, Sydenham chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.
  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (
    figure 5
    ):  Immune complex deposition on the glomerular basement membrane can lead to hematuria, proteinuria (variable), edema, hypertension, and oliguria with low C3 and CH50 levels.


Although those affected by EBV tonsillitis usually have an uncomplicated course, spontaneous splenic rupture is a serious complication that can occur in infectious mononucleosis.

Prevention



General preventive measures that reduce the risk for contracting an upper respiratory infection also apply to the prevention of tonsillitis.  These include the following:



  • Avoiding close contact or wearing masks around infected individuals until they are afebrile and their condition is clinically improving.
  • Frequently washing the hands.
  • Avoiding sharing drinks and utensils.
  • Ensuring adequate ventilation in indoor spaces.


Tonsillectomy may be considered to prevent further infection in those with recurrent bacterial tonsillitis (eg, ≥7 GAS episodes in a year).

Summary



Tonsillitis is inflammation of the palatine tonsils and is usually caused by viral infection; bacterial causes are less common.  Symptoms include fever and sore throat.  Epstein-Barr virus and bacterial infections more commonly cause exudative tonsillitis and are associated with increased risk for complications.  The diagnosis of tonsillitis is clinical, but pathogen identification is important, particularly for group A Streptococcus due to the risk for sequelae (eg, acute rheumatic fever).  Management is primarily supportive; antibiotics are prescribed for bacterial infection.
